episode.title: Tulsa Professional Collection Services, Inc. v. Pope

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Rose, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

The nature of the case to be presented in this argument involves a challenge to the constitutionality of certain Oklahoma statutes providing for notice by publication to creditors in a probate proceeding.
Section 331 of Title 58 of the Oklahoma Statutes sets forth that notice provision.
The sole notice provided is a notice by publication.

The Appellant, here and after referred to as TPCS, challenged the constitutionality of this statute for failing to provide a meaningful notice to creditors in the context of a probate proceeding that would afford due process as required by the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
Upon review of the facts in this case and an application of the Oklahoma statutory scheme, it will be clear that current Oklahoma law does not provide a meaningful notice.
It is our position that an analysis of the relevant decisions of this Court will require due process to be extended to known or reasonably ascertainable creditors.
It is further our position that contrary to assertions in various state supreme court decisions, that (1) a creditor's interest in a probate proceeding is a property right, (2)--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Rose, incidentally, did the decedent die in the hospital?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --Yes, he did, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Why weren't they then on some kind of notice that there was an estate probably to be probated?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, that--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: They certainly knew her address.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --Yes, that's true, Your Honor.
That actually is the entire crux of this case.
It is undisputed and the statement of facts will have shown that the decedent died in the hospital, and we had notice obviously that he died.
The question is not whether we had notice that he died, but whether we had notice of the initiation of the probate proceeding and the publication of the notice to creditors to file their claims.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Was this a Tulsa hospital?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Yes, it was.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: It is certainly a less sympathetic case than if your creditor were off in New York or somewhere.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: It is not the ideal case to present the issue.
However, again, the question is not whether we had notice.
No one has denied, it has been readily admitted, it's a stipulated fact that we had notice that he died.
In Oklahoma, a probate case can be filed, Title 58, Section 22 of the Oklahoma Statutes provides that a probate case can be filed at any time after the death of the decedent.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, certainly, I've known of hospitals that routinely watch the legal notices in legal newspapers--

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: --or they go down and check the probate office and get their claim in.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Your hospital just sat by and let it go, even though the death was in Tulsa and even though the decedent was a Tulsa resident.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Yes.
It would appear that way on the surface.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, isn't it so?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: It is not so.
If I may respectfully disagree with you.

In this particular case, there was an additional statutory procedure available, originally enacted in 1910, that states that the representative of the estate must pay the expenses of last illness and funeral expenses as soon as practicable after the funds come into his hands.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, that is a peculiar Oklahoma quirk, I suppose, but how does it really affect your case?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: In that situation, it is not... it has historically been the case that you do not have to file a creditor's claim to collect a bill--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Oklahoma held otherwise in this case.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --That's correct.
That's correct.

Again, I think that the difficulty is in this case, just as in this Court's decision in Mennonite Board of Missions v. Adams in 1983, and although that was a closely-divided decision in that case, the Court determined that the notice of the delinquency of taxes was not the same thing as the notice that the property was going to be sold.
In Oklahoma, in the Mennonite case, for example, there is a time period, there was a time period within which that tax sale would take place.

In Oklahoma, because of the nature of the statutes that we have to work with and as provided in Section 22 of Title 58, that notice period, the time within which to present your claim, can begin to run any time from the date of death of the decedent until forever.
Now, there is some statutory construction of this particular statute.
There are specific cases that say three years and five years and fifteen years and twenty-six years.
So, in certain specific cases, it has been as much as twenty-six years before the probate case was filed.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: And the later it goes, the less time you have to file.
As I recall, if it's five years after the death, you only get one month after the notice is published instead of two.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: So, you theoretically have to keep reading the newspapers for--

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That is the difficulty with the whole case.

You have to keep track of every debtor in every legal publication, every newspaper that's defined as a legal publication in Oklahoma, in every county in Oklahoma, and you have to read every notice that's published, every day, in order to keep track of a specific debtor.
And, again, because of the nature of the statutory scheme in Oklahoma, you have to do that for five or ten or fifteen or twenty years.

I think the interesting thing about Section 22 is that it says that the general statute of limitations, the longest one that is available in Oklahoma of five years, that general set of statutes of limitations from one to five years for different causes of action, that statute of limitations does not apply.
So, it's open.
The probate case can be filed at any time after the death.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: --Can you file a claim before the notice goes out?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: You can file a claim, but the difficulty is in discovering that a probate case is filed.
So, it's the same situation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: You don't think that's so hard, do you?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: You don't really think that's so hard, do you?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: To determine whether the probate case is filed?
Well, the only method of doing... well, you can call the courthouse every day.
You can call the court clerk's office every day and ask them if a probate case had been filed in the name of that decedent.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: I would think particularly representing a collection agency, as you do, that would be quite a staple of their business.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, again, in the context of this case and the way it arose, the fact that this Section 594 Title 58 had been relied on historically for the proposition that all funeral expenses and expenses of last illness are supposed to be paid, no mention of a claim, that is something that the hospital had done.
I think the important thing is, and I think that this is the thing that the Oklahoma Supreme Court looked at, why did the Oklahoma Supreme Court take this case.
Why did they decide this issue.
They could have said, well, wait a minute, they had actual notice, so we're not going to decide the issue.

What they did say, though, on page 7-A of the jurisdictional statement, they said that, well, the Court of Appeals was wrong in saying that the Appellee didn't... that the Appellant didn't show that they didn't have actual notice.
They said that's not the burden of the Appellant.
The Appellee's burden is to show that the proper notice was given.
All the Appellee can say is we published and that's what's required by statute.
So, we've done everything that we could.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: You don't acknowledge you have actual notice.
Are you acknowledging that you had actual notice?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Of what?
We had actual notice of the death.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Of the death.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Because the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: The death doesn't start anything running at all.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --That's right.
It starts nothing.
Nothing happens when the person dies necessarily.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: You could say the same thing about the creditor of a contract claim.
He has actual notice that his claim exists, but that's of no use until he knows that a bankruptcy proceeding has started.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's true, and I think that you may be making reference to this Court's decision in the 1953 New York v. New York-New Haven Railroad Company, where this Court decided that mailed notice was required to creditors of that debtor.
That was a railroad reorganization case, but it was not any different.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: That was decided as a matter of constitutional law?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: I believe so.

If... in that case, it's... the factual situation is extremely similar to the factual situation in this case, and even still, in that case, and as a result of the extension of the holding of that case under current bankruptcy law, current bankruptcy rules provide that a notice to creditors must be sent out within some statutory time period, sixty days or something from the time of filing.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: It just occurred to me, there's only one probate court in Tulsa, isn't there?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: So, it's only one court you have to watch?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.
But, again, Justice Marshall, you then have to call that courthouse every day for... no.
That's true.
You just have to continue to monitor... pardon me?
No, not in this case, because in this case, when the notice to creditors is published, you only have sixty days to file a claim.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Well, once every sixty days.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: You could do that and you could do that for up to apparently at least twenty-six years throughout... for every debtor that you had in every county in Oklahoma, and in every county and every state that also has a short-term non-claim statute, such as we have in Oklahoma.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But you wouldn't have had to do it very long in this case?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: In this particular case, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, that's the case we're judging.
Not some other.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: The importance, though, is that we did not have notice of the initiation of the probate proceeding and the subsequent publication of notice to creditors.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, that's true, that's true, but you could have had.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: We could have had.
I think that's an important point.
Had we had notice, if we had known, not that the decedent died, but if we had known that the probate case was filed and the notice to creditors was published,--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Oh, sure.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --then we would have filed a claim.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Sure you would have, but you could have easily found out.
It wouldn't have taken a whole lot of effort to find out in this case.
There may be some other creditors, you wouldn't expect them to inquire, but a collection agency--

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, again, in this case, this was under a different statutory scheme, that all I can tell you has been... was relied on since 1910 when the statute was enacted at the same time.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: --You're a professional organization.
That's your job, isn't it?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: This isn't an inordinate... I mean, if it's too much for you to send somebody by there once a week?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, again,--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Do you check the legal papers?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --I think that the focus should be--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: What else do you do other than bill people?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --That's it.
We try to collect the money.

I think that the focus should be on not just keeping track of a single creditor... of a single debtor, certainly keeping track of a single debtor, when you isolate on that one single creditor... that single debtor, it is easy to... you can say... you can always say you could have looked out for that single debtor... yes, but the difficulty is in doing that, in every county reading every legal publication in every county, in not only Oklahoma but in all the states that have a sixty-day, ninety-day time frame within which to file a claim.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: That hypothesizes a truly massive business of collection which would extend to every county in Oklahoma and every county in every other state of the Union.
You know, you would have to have thousands of people and presumably some of them could be assigned to reading probate notices.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That is precisely my point, and that is--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: And all of them paying fees.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: And all of them paying fees.
F-E-E-S.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: For?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: For the services that your company gives.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: You get paid for it.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: So, the more you have, the more you have to look out for.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Okay.
I agree.
The focus on the case, though, should be on... it's not conceded--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Do you think that Oklahoma should direct their laws particularly to cooperate with you, to your company?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --To cooperate with all creditors that are similarly situated.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Or the public in general.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Or in the public in general.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, it's for everyone.
It's for everyone to whom--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Not just at you because you have to go to every county--

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --That's exactly right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: --and every state.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's exactly right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Well, Oklahoma should look out for you then specially.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: No, not specially, but in conjunction with all other creditors.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Well, I mean, a single creditor wouldn't have all that trouble, would he?
You are focusing on the collection agency.
I'd like to focus on the real creditor, the hospital.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: On the hospital.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: And when was the assignment made?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: The assignment from the hospital to the collection agency?
The entities are related entities, as is reflected in the jurisdictional statement.
It is another office within the hospital.
They are separate corporations.
They operate separately.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: When you say that then, the real creditor is still the hospital.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: And I can't get much sympathy for your argument about every county and every state when you have a Tulsa decedent and a Tulsa hospital and the Tulsa probate.
Well, in Oklahoma, let me ask this, in Oklahoma, where is the probate instituted?
In the county of residence?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: It's in the county of residence.
It can be in the county where the property is located.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: But in... this decedent was a resident of this particular county.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: I can't see the great burden that is on your client, either the hospital or the collection agency.
I just can't get very sympathetic about it.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Again, when you focus on one--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Isn't that what this case is about?
One?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --It certainly is.
We can't represent... we're not representing the interests of every specific debtor, every specific creditor that there is.
In a general way, we're doing that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Rose, has any... have the lower courts determined precisely what it is the hospital had actual notice of?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: No, they have not.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Whether the hospital did have actual knowledge of a probate proceeding?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: No, no.
The stipulated facts, the only facts--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: The stipulated facts just is that the hospital knew of the death, obviously.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --That's correct.
Those are the only--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: But no other finding, is there?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --No other findings.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, if, in fact, the hospital had actual knowledge of the probate proceeding, do you lose?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: In this case, without the filing of a claim, yes.
Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: You concede that?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Didn't you say a moment ago, and if you didn't say this, please, that in Mennonite, we decided the general notice question, although in that particular case, the claimant had had notice, had had actual notice?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, the reference I made to Mennonite was that the notice of the delinquency of taxes was not the same thing as the notice of the pendency of a sale.
It's the same situation here.
The notice of the death is not the same thing as the notice of the pendency of the probate proceeding or the subsequent--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Since that might have taken place considerably later, is your point.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Since the probate proceeding might have been commenced considerably after the death.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Certainly, certainly.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: I think before we got into all the factual background of the case, you were beginning to say why this was like Mennonite, that you thought there was a property interest here.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Right.
The arguments that have been used to defeat a claim of unconstitutionality of a particular statute have included that there is no adjudication of property rights.
For example, in that specific case, the state has suggested that notice by mailing is only required, may only be required when tangible property interests are involved.

However, in the Mennonite case, there were cases cited that set forth interests that were not tangible property interests, and those included the student's right to a public education, the right to continue utility service during the time that a disputed bill remained unpaid.
The New York case example of a debt owed to a creditor in a bankruptcy proceeding as well as the Mullane example of a trustee's obligation to provide an accounting.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Of course, in the Mullane case, there was an existing interest in personal property.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And in Mennonite, there was an existing interest in real property.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And here you have what's traditionally just a claim in personam, a contract claim for payment.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's true.
But it's an intangible property interest just as a student's right to a public education is an intangible property right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But the law has always treated quite differently interests in property as opposed to contractual interests, has it not?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Yes, it has.
But the law also does not distinguish the application of the principles of due process based on a classification of property.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Many, many things certainly can be property under our due process decisions that are not classical interests in personal property or real property, but, nonetheless, I think you probably have to deal with the proposition that traditionally a statute of limitations dealing with real property is much longer than a statute of limitations dealing with contract rights and that sort of thing.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: True.

Well, another argument that has been used to defeat the claim of the unconstitutionality of a particular statute is that a non-claim statute is a statute of limitations, so that notice by publication would be sufficient.
A non-claim statute, though, is not the same either by definition or by its application as a long-term statute of limitations is the traditional statute of limitations.
In a traditional statute of limitations, there is the concept of repose for the claim and the concept that stale claims will be precluded by the running of the statutory period.
In the short-term statute that some courts have referred to as a statute of limitations, there is not that same possibility.
The idea of the claim resting, repose for the claim, doesn't exist in just a sixty-day time period, and the claim is not going to become stale in that time period.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: The interest there, I suppose, of the state is not to ward off stale claims, but to say that after someone dies, it's imperative to wind up his affairs more rapidly and you simply relied on the statute of limitations.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.

In those states with longer-term statutes, the same kinds of policy considerations or policy considerations of those states and yet, they have a true statute of limitations that is one to two up to six years.
In this non-claim statute, there is not that same consideration.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: You urge us that we should look upon them in two different ways.
So, if our next case is what, a one-year time period, we... you'd lose, but this is a sixty-day and you... what's--

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: There's a difficulty.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: --There sure is.
I mean, pick a number.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: You have to draw a line.
You have to draw a line somewhere.
The question is in applying the statute, in applying the concept of due process, is the means that you use... is it going to accomplish the purpose that you intend for it to to accomplish.
In the short-term non-claims statute, or in a longer-term non-claim statute, that idea is met.
In the shorter-term non-claims statute, it is just simply not met.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Rose, what is it that cuts off your claim?
Is it... suppose a probate proceeding is commenced but for some reason terminated,--

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: --and then a new probate proceeding is commenced, is your claim dead?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: No.
The claim... you have sixty days after the notice by publication is published to file your claim.
So that if the notice was not published, that is if the probate case is just filed and dismissed, then you would not have lost your claim.
The time period doesn't begin to run until the notice is published.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: What is the notice is published, but the probate for some reason does not go through to completion?
Is there any way that that can happen?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Well, I suppose... I don't know the answer off the top of my head.
I would suppose that perhaps it could not have.
If the probate case is filed, I mean, what is the reason?
You know, it's speculative.
What's the reason for the case being dismissed?
If it's because someone dies, they can appoint someone else.
If it's because the decedent didn't really die, of course, then that's a different situation, but it would depend on... let's just take some speculation.
It would depend on the circumstances.
Probably it wouldn't be dismissed if it was something like someone dying.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: There are very few unsuccessful probates.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's true.

I think the Court... it's necessary for the Court to look at in deciding whether due process is afforded in this case, whether it should be afforded, is to look at the state interest involved, and this is a balancing test that the dissent theory was not going to be used any longer in the Mennonite case.
Just a balancing test.
It's weighing the interests of the creditor and his right in the probate proceeding against the interest of the state in applying their laws.

The interest of the state in Oklahoma apparently is strictly and nothing else order, finality of proceedings and quick settlement of estate, and I say this because in 1965, the statute was reduced, the time period in which to file claims was reduced from four months to the current two-month period.
If the--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Would you be satisfied with four months?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --No.
Again, that's a legislative determination.
I would think that one year would be long enough for all claims to come to the attention--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Many other states have four months.
As an old probate hand, I know that.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --Yes.
Some states have four months.
Some states have two, two states have two months, some states have six, and some states have a year or two years up to six years.
I'd like to reserve the rest of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Rose.
We'll hear now from you, Mr. Smith.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

Immediately, I would like to address several statements made by Appellant Hospital, both in their jurisdictional statement in their briefs as well as in the oral argument just concluded that are no where to be found in the record.
These are very pertinent statements.

The most blatant of which is that the personal representative had actual knowledge of the claim of the hospital at the time her husband died as well as at the time that notice to creditors was published.

For the first six years after the death of the decedent, the Appellant Hospital relied exclusively on the Oklahoma statute that set out certain preferences and priorities of payment under Section 594 of our Probate Code, and no court thus far has decided that that relieved them of the burden of filing a notice to creditors, that not until the case had been tried on that issue in the original probate court, had been heard by the Oklahoma Court of Appeals, and upon petition for rehearing to the Oklahoma Court of Appeals, approximately August of 1985, did the Appellant Hospital raise the issue of due process.
Now, up until that point, the exclusive question before the court was the question of priority of payment of debts.
The fact that the personal representative had actual knowledge of the claim is no where to be found in the record, and we dispute that fact, and we have continually disputed it in our brief.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, that's just never been decided, I take it.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That's correct.
It was never--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Who knew what has not been decided.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --That's correct.
There was never an opportunity to try the facts on the due process issue.
We have maintained--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: If the case goes back, it can be determined?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --That's correct.

We are ready to meet that issue as a matter of fact because we maintain that she had no knowledge of any claim pending at the time either that he died or the time that she published notice to creditors.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Do you also maintain that the hospital knew of the probate proceeding?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: We do not maintain that they knew of the probate proceeding at the time that he died or that we gave them actual notice.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I guess there wasn't a probate proceeding before he died.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That's right.
We don't know when the hospital found out about the probate proceeding.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Just to get in my mind a couple of the dates here.
The date of death was April 2nd, 1979, and the notice to creditors was published in July of that year?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And the first claim filed by the collection agency here was in October 1983?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That was not a claim.
We disputed, and this has never been a part of the record, that they ever filed a claim.
In October of 1983, they made application for the first time during the whole probate to compel the personal representative to pay their claim based on a priority of payments under Section 594.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: That was the first appearance they had made in the probate action?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Kennedy
turn.text: Had there been any preliminary distributions from the estate?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: No.
There is only one sole heir and that is the personal representative, the wife of the deceased, and she had not taken any distribution.
It might be important to get the dates in order in the record.
It is in the record that the decedent was admitted to St. John Medical Center on November of 1978.
He never left the hospital building until his death on April 2nd of 1979.
Now, she was appointed the personal representative and duly published on July 17th, 1979, and as the Chief Justice pointed out, the claims period then ran until September 17th, 1979.
Actually, some five and a half months after the date of death.
And in Oklahoma, the sixty-day period does not commence until the first date of publication.
It's not two months from the date of death.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Smith, what if we had here a creditor from out of state with no knowledge of the death or the probate proceeding, do you think that publication notice under the Oklahoma statute would be... would meet due process requirements?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: There is an exception as are several exceptions under the non-claims statute.
One provides for an out of state creditor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: If you know about them.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: If you know about them.
You can't give notice to out of state creditors personally unless you know about them.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Right.
But concerning out of state creditors, they are exempt from the two-month time period.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, then, let's make it an in state creditor without any knowledge at all.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: There are no exemptions made for in state creditors, just on the basis that they had no knowledge.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, that isn't my question.
I'm not asking about the operation of the statute.
I'm asking you whether you would say that due process would require something more than publication notice to such creditors.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: No.
We would say that they would not be entitled to it under due process.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: You would have to because actually all the Oklahoma law provides for the out of state creditors the longer period.
He still can be barred once the decree is entered.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That is true.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Once the decree is entered, he's out, whether he gives notice or not.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: He has until the final decree of distribution, which could be months or years, depending on the case.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Right.
What was the reason, if any, that notice was not given to the hospital?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Notice was not given for two reasons.
One, Mrs. Pope did not realize and recognize the hospital as a creditor of the estate.
Two,--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, the hospital bill was outstanding, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --The hospital bill was outstanding.

She, and this is not in the record, sir, I want to clarify that, she had reason to believe in her mind that the estate, including herself personally, would never be liable for a penny from this expense because of insurance.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, were you counsel for the estate and for her?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes.
Our firm was.
I wasn't personally.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, did the firm share her belief?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: I can't answer that as far--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: But you can answer my question.
Why didn't the firm give the hospital notice?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --Well, it wasn't required under the non-claims statute.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Was it because they hoped they would avoid the filing of a claim and the necessity of paying it?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: No, sir.
The--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Are we playing games in Oklahoma?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --No.

The point could be argued that an unscrupulous personal representative could play behind the laws and wait until the filing period was over and then step in and say, your bill is out because you didn't file.

In this case, claims were paid as a matter of fact, and this is not in the record either, but claims were paid and declared as deductions for estate tax returns, both to the IRS and the Oklahoma Tax Commission.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, those claims had been filed, I take it.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: No, they weren't.
They were paid without having been filed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: She still paid them?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But you knew about them and paid them?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And you didn't give the hospital notice because you were relying on the public notice?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir, and we didn't recognize the claim of the hospital.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Did you have any trouble with the IRS who would... I've known them in the past to insist on the formal filing and allowance of claims before they allow them as deductions.
Did you have any trouble?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: We had no trouble with the IRS on that question and received releases from both tax entities.

The reason I mentioned the deduction on the tax return is that to show the good faith of Mrs. Pope because she did not declare any money due and owing to St. John Medical Center, and for a $14,000 deduction, had she known of that, she would have taken it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, she would have had to pay it.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: She would have had to pay it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: There certainly is a financial interest in the heirs at least in avoiding notice to creditors, isn't there?
I mean, certainly the potential heir will enhance the estate if creditors don't know.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That's true.
There would be a potential if heirs--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Do you think the Constitution would require that you give at least public notice?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --I believe that public notice is required under the due process clause.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Because of the uncertainty of determining who and who is not a creditor.
I believe it puts all of the creditors in the same boat to alert the public and the creditors at large that there is a proceeding which might affect their interests.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: What do you mean, the uncertainty of knowing who... you say unscrupulous administrator or executor might not notify known creditors.
Is it clear where scrupulousness lies?
I mean, I assume the obligation of the executor is to maximize the estate that can be passed on to the heirs.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: As well as pay any valid debts.
The--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Well, but a debt's not valid if it's not presented in time.
It's barred.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: He has an obligation to make sure that everybody doesn't file in time and files in time.
I'm not sure where his obligation lies.

If I were in that position and I knew that my obligation under law is just to publish notice, that I've opened up this estate, you sure that I have an obligation to these creditors that I know of rather than to the potential distributees?
I'm not sure where that lies.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: I still believe that under the oath of office that an executor takes, they are under a duty to not only protect the rights of the heirs and the property interests, but also to pay any valid debts of the estate.
I still believe that there is a dual role there to be played.
In this case, the personal representative happens to be the wife of the deceased, and there is a close tie there.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Is the obligation to pay debts valid when all the debts are in and if these are never presented,--

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: --they're not valid debts?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That's correct.

I would also state that the practice in Oklahoma as well as possibly other jurisdictions is to pay claims, even though proper creditors claims are not presented, and this is done and while if you have an executor who has to answer to some heirs who wouldn't have done that themselves, it is done on a practical basis every day.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Well, in response to that, I know of at least four jurisdictions where that is not true.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: In Oklahoma, it is the practice.
The reason--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: You made the statement you thought it was generally the practice, and I questioned that one.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --In Oklahoma, excuse me, insurance payments continue to be made by the employer sponsored insurance carrier until approximately February of 1980.

So, as to the determination of the debt, not only when he died, but when she gave notice to creditors, she didn't know any exact amount and I dare say the hospital didn't know because it could have, in fact, been paid off in full.

So, at best, it was a contingent claim and provisions are made under the same Oklahoma non-claims statute, Section 333, for contingent claims, and it provides that a creditor of a contingent or unmatured debt is to present the claim in that form to the personal representative, and depending on when the claim becomes due, depends how far the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: How is the person supposed to do it if the creditor doesn't know about the opening of the estate?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --Well, the creditor, we maintain, is supposed to monitor those accounts that they have to collect.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, why do they give this exception... the exception for the out of state people is because they don't read the newspapers that the Oklahoma citizens have available to them.
That's the point.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: I would assume because they wouldn't have access to the newspapers.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: But the ordinary creditor has to read all the legal publications to protect himself or herself.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: That would be correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And we haven't talked much about whether the statute is constitutional.
We've had an interesting discussion of Oklahoma probate law, but do you think the statute is constitutional?
Do you think that's adequate notice to the average creditor?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Sixty days.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Sixty days.
Sounds like a short stream, but it's not always sixty days.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Sixty days plus the period of time between the date of death and the time the publication is made.
You have a prompt estate opening and a prompt publication, it could be a matter of ninety days, I would assume, in a lot of cases.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: The original hearing cannot be less than ten days or more than thirty days from whenever the petition is filed.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: It is usually filed within a couple of weeks.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: In this case, it was a period of over five months that they had to file their claim.

We maintain that that is reasonable and the legislature, for some reason in 1965, shortened the period from four months to two months, citing the state purpose of expediting and closing estates as well as the proper presentation of validation of debts.
These claims aren't just presented on a piece of paper.
They have to be validated.
They have to be properly shown so that she knows that she's paying a rightful debt.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: What's the big deal about notifying known creditors?
Why does that have to delay the closing of the estate?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: We don't argue with the idea that actual notice is preferable in most all cases.
The problem, Justice Scalia, in a probate matter is that who is the known creditor, and that is the problem here.
She knew St. John's.
She had been there many times.
She knew their address.
She knew how to get there.
She knew how to find their mailing address.
But as to whether or not they were a known creditor of this estate, she didn't know them in that sense at all.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Yes, but for purposes of our decision in reviewing the court below, they assumed for purposes of decision that she may well have known them and still didn't have to give them notice.
Don't we have to decide whether there's any obligation even when the representative of the estate does know?
I mean, you may be right as a matter of fact that she didn't know, but that hasn't been tried out, has it?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: No, that has not been tried.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: So, don't we have to, to decide this case, assume that everybody knew... that she knew the facts and could well have given notice and wouldn't have slowed anything up at all if she said, well, I don't think the hospital bill is paid, I think I ought to write them a letter?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: We maintain that to do that causes a burden upon personal representatives who are not always the spouse of the decedent, to find out exactly who the creditors are, and this is a genuine problem where personal representatives who has some times only desks or drawers of papers to go through in order to determine who the creditors are.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yes, but the question Justice Stevens poses is whatever kind of administrator you have, if the administrator actually knows of a creditor, must he give them notice.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Not under this statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, the question is, does the Constitution require more.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: I don't believe so.
If you assume... just take an example.

Let's say Mr. Pope had some outside business interests and this is not uncommon for people to do this without making it a matter of record, let's assume that he took loans out before he died to a person we'll call John or a person by the name of Mary.
He didn't tell his wife about this.
Wasn't filed of record.
These were strictly loans that he chose to do with what he pleased, but he died and neither one of them were repaid.
He happened to leave some notes about one of them laying around the house.
The one to John.
The wife found that.
She said, I think he had something going on with John, let's give John notice.
But what about Mary?
Neither Mary nor John happened to find out about Mr. Pope's death and thus much less know about a probate.
It's not fair, we urge the Court, that Mary should be left out even though she had the same legal position as John.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: I come back to the facts of this case.
Her husband was in the hospital for several weeks.
Surely she knew a hospital bill was accumulating.
I would be surprised if she didn't know whether or not it was paid.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: She had prior experience with this hospital.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: If the executor were the First National Bank of Tulsa, if you have one, they certainly would have investigated it.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: This goes outside the record again, but to answer your question, a personal representative, the wife of the deceased, had prior experiences with this hospital and with this husband and with this insurance carrier in which she never had to pay a dime.
She assumed and had reason to believe that she wouldn't have to pay any this time and, therefore, did not recognize them as a creditor of this estate.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, sooner or later, it became evident that the hospital was and that the bill was unpaid.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And is there some rule in Oklahoma that an administrator can't pay a valid debt after the claims period has run?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --No, sir.
She could have paid it.
In this case, she didn't believe... once she was presented, which was more than over a year after her husband's death was the first notice or communication that she received from the hospital.
In April, approximately, of 1980.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Then, there was no doubt that the bill was valid, was there?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: There was in her mind.
She still believed at that point that insurance would cover because insurance had been making payments sporadically over a period of months.
The most recent one having been around February of 1980, about two months prior to receiving that letter.
The letter she received did not indicate any past due amount was owed.
It merely stated this is the balance of the account.
She believed that insurance would cover it and she never heard again from either the hospital or their collection agency until approximately 1982.
Up to this point, they had never filed anything in the case until October of 1983, some four and a half years after the probate had been initiated.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Kennedy
turn.text: If we rule in favor of the Appellant, is there a concern that the cost of probate will escalate because the cost of executor bonds will be higher, etcetera?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes, Justice Kennedy, that is one concern.

We concede that a twenty-two cent stamp to give notice is not a problem, but there could possibly be a problem with responsibility upon the fiduciary to perform under their bond and to give notice because under the earlier example of John and Mary, Mary comes in and says my due process rights were violated, I didn't get notice.
I'm going to sue you and she may have a claim against not only the executor but the heirs later down the road.
Another--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Smith, suppose Oklahoma wants to provide an easy way for its citizens to get credit, to re-establish their credit, so it provides for a declaratory judgment scheme in which you can file a declaratory judgment action seeking to have a pronouncement that there are no outstanding debts against you or exactly what claims there are against you, and it adopts the same system we have here, you simply have public notice of the suit by publishing it in a newspaper and any creditor who doesn't come in within sixty days, asserting a claim, shall be barred, and you'll get a declaratory judgment that that debt is no longer relevant, do you think that would be constitutional?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --I would ask, does the debtor have knowledge of the identity of the creditors in that case, and if so,--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --Excuse me.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Does the debtor have knowledge?
Yes.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Yes.
If they have knowledge, that's one thing, and in order to declare a declaratory judgment, I believe that this Court's decisions would find grounds to declare that unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Now, why is this different?
Why couldn't I call that a statute of limitations just as well as you want us to call this one a statute of limitations?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Because in this case, there was no declaratory judgment nor are there in probate matters.

It's simply the running of the statute which is similar to the case of Texaco, Inc., v. Short, decided by this case, in which it determined that the running of a statute of limitations acts to cut those potential claims off as opposed to a declaratory judgment in Mullane and Mennonite.
That is one of the distinctions that we draw.
The Appellant Hospital in this case attempted six years after the probate was started to draw the facts of this case to fit under the third Moseley case that came out of the Supreme Court of Nevada.
The facts do not apply at all.
In that third Moseley case, the personal representative had actual knowledge of the creditors' claims.
The creditor had a pending lawsuit against the deceased at the time of death.
The creditor in Moseley did not know xx the death of the decedent until the final day for filing claims and they filed two days late.
That wasn't deemed to be fair and I don't believe that it was fair, but it's not the facts of this case.
That's why it's important to understand some of the facts as they have been stated in the briefs that are not in the record and which distinguish the case on that basis.
I think there's also--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: How do you distinguish the City of New York case holding that notice by publication was not sufficient for creditors in filing claims in a bankruptcy estate?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --I think part of the answer goes to the nature of a bankruptcy versus the nature of a probate action.
The whole nature of the case in New York that you're referring to has to do with getting the bankrupt debtor a fresh start in that case, a reorganization under another company.
That debtor in the New York case knew of New York City's existing interest in the real property.
Not only that, but in that particular case, the judge, according to the findings, failed to properly follow the statute in requiring all creditors to be given mailed notice.
Another distinction is that the notice that was given to the creditors in that New York bankruptcy case had to do of a court order.
It was not the running of the statute of limitations.
It was the court order that they were supposed to have given notice to New York City about that they failed to do.

So, I think from that standpoint, there are several distinguishing factors between a bankruptcy in which all creditors were known or the debtor wouldn't be in the bankruptcy court to begin with because he knows who's putting the pressure on him from the credit standpoint.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Smith, is there any provision in the Oklahoma Probate Code that requires the executor or the administrator to make any kind of representation to the court that all known debts have been paid?

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: There is not currently a requirement.
It is frequent in orders allowing final accounts that all creditors who have filed claims have been paid.
Maybe that was your question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: No.
Apart from the requirement that those who have filed claims have been paid.
The first clause of most wills says and pay all just debts and so forth.
There's no requirement that they have to represent to the probate court that that's been done, other than those that are actually filed.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: Right.

We maintain that the Hospital Appellant had several opportunities in which to protect itself under the broad scope of due process and no one can define what due process is in any single word or two, but we suggest that it represents a fair or reasonable opportunity.
Sometimes, such as in Mullane and Mennonite, this fair or reasonable opportunity requires a hearing before the state cuts off a creditor's interest.

But sometimes it does not require a hearing, such as in the Texaco case, and we believe that ample opportunity is made under the Oklahoma non-claims statute for debtors or, excuse me, for creditors to present their claims and have them adjudicated.
If a creditor is going to do business in a state and loan money to people and perform services for people, they better become aware of the law.
That relates not only to probate law, they better be aware of the tax laws.
In a hospital case, they better be aware of negligence law, and in Texaco, this Court held that presumption of the statutes is made by the Court when a statute of limitations is at question.
We determine that no less is true here.
We believe that--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: This applies, of course, not just to people doing business, but this could have been his cousin at the other side of the state who loaned him money.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: So, it's not just people that are in business, it's any debt.

turn.speaker: phillip_k_smith
turn.label: Mr. Phillip K. Smith
turn.text: People who do business.
Maybe I should have said that.

People who do business, and if Aunt Sue loans money to a nephew and Aunt Sue has been a homemaker for thirty years and she doesn't normally transact business, she better know certain things about usury laws or perhaps she's violating those.
So, there is a duty on any person who transacts certain types of business to be aware of the law or to find out about the law.
The hospital in this case handled business and has people die in its wards every day.
They know what the law is.
They failed to do their job by not filing a creditor's claim and finding out about the probate.

We pray the Court to affirm the Supreme Court of Oklahoma in favor of the estate and not allow facts outside the record to be twisted into the confines of the Moseley case, the Texaco case, and the Mullane case.
If there are no further questions, thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Smith.
Mr. Rose, you have three minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
Justice Stevens, I believe, was asking a question about how quickly can that time period pass within which to file your claims.
In Oklahoma, the representative is required to publish the notice within thirty days of his appointment.
The wording in the statute is: must be revoked, but then follows by: unless good cause is shown.
The practice is and what is preferred by the Court is to publish a notice within thirty days and then you end up with a ninety-day time period.
I believe you had that question.
Justice Scalia, I believe, was asking a question about the difficulty in the unscrupulous personal representative hiding behind the log to use the Appellee's terminology.
They paid some claims and they didn't pay some claims.
The decedent was in the hospital for a number of months, had a $142,000 hospital bill, and says I didn't know that there was any money still owing.
Again, a lot of these facts are outside the record, and it makes it difficult for the Court and--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: But, Mr. Rose, if you win, doesn't the case have to go back for trial on the question of whether the administrator actually knew about the claim?

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: --Well, not if... that would be fine.
I believe that if the statute is unconstitutional as applied, that that would not be necessary.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: If the only constitutional requirement is that the people who have actual notice be... I mean, people of whom the decedent's representative actually knew to have claims, your client would not prevail unless she knew that there was an outstanding claim.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: Okay.
Yes, I believe that's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And that has not yet been adjudicated.

turn.speaker: randall_e_rose
turn.label: Mr. Randall E. Rose
turn.text: That's correct.
I believe Justice Scalia also asked what's the problem with giving notice to known creditors.
There's not really a problem.
What would be required of a representative in that kind of situation?
Due diligence.
This is making up the law now.
What kind of requirements should we have?
Due diligence, reasonable inquiry on the part of the personal representative.
In seeking to notify... to ascertain and notify creditors, on his appointment--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Rose.
The case is submitted.
